title: 103_s1782
content: The Act may be cited as the "Electronic Freedom of Information Improvement Act of 1994". The Congress finds that the purpose of the Freedom of Information Act is to make agency information available for public inspection, leading to the disclosure of government operations, waste, fraud, and abuse. The Freedom of Information Act aims to ensure public access to agency records, improve transparency, and promote democracy by disclosing government operations and preventing abuse. Government agencies are encouraged to use new technology to enhance public access to valuable information. SEC. 3. PUBLIC INFORMATION AVAILABILITY. Section 552(a)(1) of title 5, United States Code, is amended to include electronic means for accessing information and a list of statutes authorizing information withholding. SEC. 4. MATERIALS MADE AVAILABLE IN ELECTRONIC FORMAT. Section 552(a)(2) of title 5, United States Code, is amended to include provisions for electronic access to agency records and the creation of an index of major information systems containing agency records. The amendment includes provisions for electronic access to agency records and the creation of an index of major information systems. It also requires a description of any new major information system and how it will enhance agency operations. Additionally, it specifies that any deletions in records must be indicated in the published version. SEC. 5. LIST OF RECORDS MADE AVAILABLE TO THE PUBLIC AND HONORING FORMAT REQUESTS. Section 552(a)(3) of title 5, United States Code is amended to include provisions for making records available to the public for inspection and copying. This includes providing a list of records available to any person and making copies of records that are likely to be requested available for inspection and copying. An agency must provide records in any form requested by a person, including electronic formats, even if not usually maintained in that form. SEC. 6. DELAYS. The text discusses the allocation of fees collected under section 552(a)(4)(A) of title 5, United States Code, with half credited to the collecting agency for compliance costs and the remaining fees remitted to the Treasury. Additionally, it addresses the payment of expenses for individuals making requests under section 552(a)(4)(E) of title 5, United States Code. The text discusses the allocation of fees collected under section 552(a)(4)(A) of title 5, United States Code, with half credited to the collecting agency for compliance costs and the remaining fees remitted to the Treasury. It also addresses the payment of expenses for individuals making requests under section 552(a)(4)(E) of title 5, United States Code, including attorney fees for non-compliance by the agency. The text discusses amendments to section 552(a)(6)(A)(i) and (C) of title 5, United States Code, regarding timeframes for processing requests for records, agency backlogs, and notification of denials. The amendment to section 552(a)(6) of title 5, United States Code introduces a multitrack FIFO processing policy for handling requests, with separate tracks for simple and complex requests based on processing time. The amendment introduces a multitrack FIFO processing policy for handling requests, with separate tracks for simple and complex requests based on processing time. Agencies must determine within 5 days whether to comply with a request for expedited access to records, and notify the requester of the decision within one day. A request for expedited access to records must be processed promptly. If expedited access is denied, the request must still be processed within specified time limits. If a decision on expedited access is not made within 5 days, the requester must exhaust administrative remedies. Appeals can be made to the head of the agency within specific timeframes. The requester must exhaust administrative remedies if expedited access is denied or not decided within 5 days. A court may require the agency to show cause for denying expedited access. The burden of demonstrating a compelling need for expedited access can be met by certifying under penalty of perjury. The requester can seek expedited access to information if it threatens life or safety, results in loss of due process rights, or affects public assessment of governmental actions under widespread media coverage. SEC. 7. COMPUTER REDACTION. Amends Section 552(b) of title 5, United States Code to require indication of deletions on released records. SEC. 8. DEFINITIONS. Section 552(f) of title 5, United States Code is amended to define terms such as 'agency', 'record', and 'search' for the purpose of conducting manual or automated reviews of agency records. The amendment to Section 552(f) of title 5, United States Code defines terms for reviewing agency records, including those responsive to specific requests. The Senate passed the amendment on August 25, 1994. Attest: MARTHA S. POPE, Secretary.
